If ever there was a movie to make you lose faith in the field of paid movie critics
column22: this is it. The glowing reviews done by the majority of "professional" critics looks like some repugnant fetish for anything "subversive
column23:
no matter how clumsily, poorly thought out, and defacing to the original property the subversion" is. Subversion can be a great thing when it\'s skillfully done. It isn\'t here.

This is a bad movie. It\'s tempting to focus on the poor pacing
column26: and general aura of incompetence the characters labor under (Holdo keeping her plan secret despite knowing the Resistance fighters are in a desperate situation and badly demoralized; the amazingly inept plan to go to the casino planet that felt stupidly circuitous the moment it was spoken
column29:
etc.)

But while its tempting to look at those things
column30: which make it a bad watch
column31: the worst thing about it is simply Rian Johnson\'s decision that time and old age had made Luke into essentially the opposite of what he was
column32: to the point where the audience feels disgust with a person they were fond of. Luke is an apathetic jerk. It may subvert audience expectations
column33:
but only because it demonstrates a complete disrespect for the original trilogy that birthed the franchise.

Finally
column34: this movie doesn\'t just damage the original trilogy
column35: it also retroactively makes the Force Awakens look like a time bomb of bad ideas that have now gone off. The decisions to have the First Order just replace the Empire
column37: Luke replace Obi Wan as a Jedi who taught a corrupted pupil... it all undermined the accomplishments of the first films
column38: but at least the audience believed we\'d get a serious and intelligent effort in the Last Jedi to answer the questions of how that happened. No such effort was made. Force Awakens was derivative and never thought two steps ahead. The Last Jedi cements that no effort was put into thinking those things through
column39:
while taking a seemingly perverse pleasure in tainting whatever fond feelings you still had for Luke Skywalker.

I\'d prefer to give this movie zero stars if I could
column40: but since the lowest score you can give is half a star
column41: I\'ll say that the half-star goes to the music
column42: which remains stellar (John Williams has never disappointed with any soundtrack
column43: the soundtrack is the only good thing to come out of this movie). '

Roy P
\xbd January 11
column69:
2018
Did this movie ruin Star Wars? Of course not but it didn\'t make it better or worse. just whatever. People are pointing fingers at the die-hards like our expectations were too high Maybe but I argue that\'s Disney\'s fault for marketing the movie the way they did. JJ already created intriguing mysteries that were changing he Star Wars lore. I don\'t know why critics are defending this movie saying sw fans don\'t want anything new. Are you kidding me? We\'ve been waiting for something new FOREVER. It\'s obvious that they didn\'t have a game plan for this franchise. I\'ll still see episode 9 but I don\'t know if I care considering what they did to snoke. The fans have been waiting for some backstory on this foool since day one and they trolled us. The worst part is they\'d knew we\'d be upset but did it anyways. I was nervous about jj coming back but now maybe not. If story continuity is synonymous with fan service then I\'ll take a fan service movie. At least the fans pay attention to your story elements
'

Jonathan J
\xbd January 11
column71:
2018
This movie raped me of my childhood memories and sense of hope.

Before you waste your time seeing this horrific film let me describe what it feels like to watch it if you are a fan of the Original George Lucas Trilogy...

You feel as if though you\'re a 5 year old kid again and are gleefully playing with your Vintage Millennium Falcon Toy Ship
column72: full of imagination and hope for the universe. Then Rian Johnson walks into the room. He grabs the ships out of your hand and opens the top bay doors. He proceeds to drop his drawers and piss into the toy a few feet in front of your face. You sit there stunned like THE DUDE in the Big Lebowski and simply mutter "Not in the Millennium Falcon
column73: man!." Then just when you think he is done
column74:
Rian turns around and takes an actual dump inside the Falcon. Rian mercifully exits the room.

Despite feeling completely mortified and scarred by the experience
column75: you gather yourself together and approach you cherished
column76: childhood toy to assess the damages. Then
column77: just as you start to get a new hope that the Falcon can somehow be cleaned up
column78:
Kathleen Kennedy and the Mickey Mouse Clubhouse Gang from Disney come into the room and start stomping the Falcon into smithereens like it\'s a Friggin HOT DIGGITY DOG jamboree!

Holding back tears at this point
column80:
enter a bunch of innocent looking Porgs who are carrying torches of Wookie fur. They proceed to start the entire room on fire.

Finally
column81:
you can\'t bear it any longer and are forced to leave the premises.
Then you spend the next 24-48 hours in a daze
column83: wondering how and why this happened and whether or not it could be fixed
column84:
undone or erased from existence. ????????????????????

It CAN NOT. It\'s over. Everything you once loved about this franchise and the magic of it\'s movie making is gone.

Stick a fork in it and milk a green tit.

STAR WARS is done. '

The only reason TLJ gets two stars from me is because visually it is beautiful. Rian Johnson knows what he is doing behind the camera. Behind the script
column115: not so much. Upon my first viewing of this film I came away feeling confused and dissatisfied. There were many scenes that bothered me but I couldn\'t quite tell you why. I\'ve since seen it three more times and I can now say with confidence that TLJ is plot hole city. There are writing errors through out that are tough to detect but once you start to see them they become glaringly obvious. I wanted to like this film so much; but I am afraid that all it did for me is drag my opinion of it\'s predecessor The Force Awakens down with it. The films are supposed to be connected but Rian seemingly decided to throw the baby out with the bath water and do his own thing. Being a Star Wars fan since I was a child in the early 80\'s this is the first Star Wars film that I did not have an over all good time watching; including the prequels. '
